tattoos.name: First Marathon
tattoos.description: 03:29:18 displayed as it would read on an analog clock
tattoos.meaning: My first marathon time - a project with a beginning, middle, and end. I qualified for Boston. It represents completing something I set out to do.

tattoos.name: Squirrel
tattoos.description: A very simple line drawing of a squirrel

tattoos.name: Elephant in the Boa
tattoos.description: The elephant inside a boa constrictor from The Little Prince
tattoos.meaning: A tribute to the beauty of children's imagination - the way children see what adults cannot. In the book, adults see only a hat, but the child sees the elephant swallowed by the snake. A reminder to preserve wonder and to truly see.

tattoos.name: Our Eruptions
tattoos.description: A volcano, from Nietzsche's The Gay Science
tattoos.meaning: From Nietzsche's The Gay Science, Book I, Aphorism #9. We contain immense energy beneath the surface - talents and strengths that developed weakly in earlier stages, suddenly thrust into light after years. We are all growing volcanoes waiting for our hour of eruption.
tattoos.quote: Numberless things which humanity acquired in its earlier stages, but so weakly and embryonically that it could not be noticed that they were acquired, are thrust suddenly into light long afterwards, perhaps after the lapse of centuries: they have in the interval become strong and mature. In some ages this or that talent, this or that virtue seems to be entirely lacking, as it is in some men; but let us wait only for the grandchildren and grandchildren's children, if we have time to wait, they bring the interior of their grandfathers into the sun, that interior of which the grandfathers themselves were unconscious. The son, indeed, is often the betrayer of his father; the latter understands himself better since he has got his son. We have all hidden gardens and plantations in us; and by another simile, we are all growing volcanoes, which will have their hours of eruption: how near or how distant this is, nobody of course knows, not even the good God.
tattoos.source: Friedrich Nietzsche â€” The Gay Science, Book I, Aphorism #9: Our Eruptions

tattoos.name: Es Muss Sein
tattoos.description: The phrase 'Es muss sein' (It must be)
tattoos.meaning: From Milan Kundera's The Unbearable Lightness of Being. The phrase represents the weight of necessity - the idea that some things in life feel inevitable, fated. Kundera explores how we give meaning to our choices by treating them as necessary rather than accidental. It's about finding purpose in commitment, even in a world where everything could just as easily be otherwise.

tattoos.name: Bike Lane
tattoos.description: A bike with two arrows above representing a bike lane
tattoos.meaning: Movement, urban life, the simple joy of riding.

tattoos.name: Honey Pot
tattoos.description: A honey pot with honey streaming down

tattoos.meaning: The apartment number of my first home in DC. I lived there for four or five years - it was where I built my life after college.

tattoos.name: Hummingbird
tattoos.meaning: I saw a hummingbird for the first time, even though my mom always bought feeders for them. When I told her the story, she said her brother had just died - they had talked about hummingbirds before he passed. I had seen it the same day he died. A connection across distance.

tattoos.name: Yellow Umbrella
tattoos.description: An umbrella above the inside of my right hand
tattoos.meaning: How I Met Your Mother - the life lessons and the belief in timing, destiny, and finding your person.

tattoos.name: Cowboy Hat
tattoos.meaning: Matching tattoo with my sister. We're from Dallas - it's a Texan thing.

tattoos.name: Tiny Spoon
tattoos.description: A tiny spoon running along the outside of my wrist
tattoos.meaning: For my love of small spoons. All scoopable food tastes more delicious when eaten with a tiny spoon.

tattoos.name: So It Goes
tattoos.meaning: From Kurt Vonnegut's Slaughterhouse-Five. The phrase appears after every death in the book - a quiet acknowledgment of mortality without sentimentality. It's about acceptance: life and death happen, time is not linear, and we keep going. Neither dismissive nor dramatic, just true.
